content.description:
Climb (or moreso scramble) up an easy right-facing corner to a high first bolt just above a small roof. From there continue straight up a face.Â 



Starts immediately left of where the trail enters Lower Kid Goat area. The start is to climb up a prominent right-facing corner on easy terrain to a high first bolt.

Bolts and bolted anchor

This beautiful route is a classic 5.8 sport route. Cool moves, excellent rock, and great exposure define this route.  
  
 Pitch 1 (5.8 - 50m) - Climb up an arrete then out onto the face. Pass at possibly belay at 20m. Cross three overhangs to the belay station (shared with Keel Haul Wall), the second overhang is the toughest.  
  
 Pitch 2 (5.8 - 25m) - ignore the bolt on the overhang to the right; this belongs to KHW; instead move stright up from the belay past two fixed pins and a possible, bomber 'knot' placement (jam a prussick into the crack; you know you want to!) move right onto the slab to the first bolt (30' runout). Climb up to the crux overhang the over and to the anchor. 
  
 Pitch 3 (5.7 - 30m) Traverse to the right to the obvious, bolt protected weakness then straight up following the hard to see bolts to the anchor. 
  
 Pitch 4 (5.7 - 30m) Traverse right along the bolts on easy slab, there is one tricky vertical spot half way up. 
  
 Pitch 5 (5.6 - 20m) Follow the bolts to the left along the slab to the obvious top out (usually pretty slimy rock here). Belay off the tree. 
  
 Decent: Walk off as for KHW.

Located slightly left of Keel Haul Wall, look for the bolts 5 meters left of the start of KHW, start from the small bay.
Alpine Sport - significant runouts between bolts on easy terrain, but all cruxs are well protected. Exposure and runouts can be intimidating for the new leader.

Pitch 1 5.6 30m

Climb the easier 5.6 section up the wall until you reach a large alcove with a single bolt off to the left below the roof.

Pitch 2 5.9 30m

Step right and then ascend the next series of bolts to the top of the wall, expect confusion as it borders an adjacent route. Take whichever one seems like more fun.

Rap the route

Just to the right of the Keelhaul Wall
Quickdraws

Climb through a more difficult section for the first three bolts (those visible from the ground) before going over a bulge where the difficulty eases and the bolt spacing increases, before another well bolted crux just before the anchor.



Starts approximately 15 metres right of where the trail enters Lower Kid Goat area. Is the second route to the right of a large prominent tree growing on the cliff ~15m up.

Bolted and bolted anchor.

Climb up with good hands. At the top move to the the left to the adjacent anchor, as the anchor on this route does not have rappel rings



Second bolted line from the far right side of the crag (where there is an obvious groove where the crag ends)

Bolted with bolted anchors

This route is the perfect introduction to limestone trad. The rock quality is moderate to high, the protection is very good by Rockies standards. Commitment is low as any pitch can be rapped with two ropes. As with all Rockies trad route, the use of double rope techniques is highly encouraged. 
  
 Pitch 1 (5.5 - 20m): Trend up and right on the slab to a bolt, then straight up past 1 more bolt and a possible nut placement to a 2 bolt anchor. 
  
 Pitch 2 (5.6 - 30m): Traverse left, up and back right around an overhang. Follow the left facing corner protected by fixed pins (possible small nut backups are advisable). A few smearing moves lead to a large ledge with a bolt anchor.  
  
 Pitch 2a (4th - 5m): Move the belay to the fixed station left side of the ledge. Watch for loose rock. This station is shared by Grey Waves. 
  
 Pitch 3 (5.6 - 30m): The 'keel haul pitch'. Traverse left until it's possible to comfortably move up. Protection is a mix of fixed pins and bolts. Proceed up and left on the rough slab to a belay station. Rope drag is a serious problem on this pitch, bring plenty of long slings. 
  
 Pitch 4 (5.5 - 40m): Go straight up the slab with good but sparse protection. Come up between two large trees to a bolt belay. 
  
 Pitch 5 (5.5+ - 30m): Go straight up the slab crossing two vertical sections protected by fixed pins (very small cams as back up) to the top out. Bolts at the top out point. 
  
 Descent: Walk right along the top of the cliff and then east down to the river gully between kid and nanny goat buttress. Walk down the gully crossing to the north side of the creek (icy in early season). Scramble down 4th class slab to a trail acorss the creek and back to the base of the cliffs.

Follow the cliff band to the south watching for the letters KHW and an arrow written on the wall. This is the start of the route.
Mixed trad, bolts and fixed pins; bring a light rack: 1 nut set, Cams to #1 or #2 camalot.

Climb up solid slab rock with good feet.



Starts approximately 10-15m right of where the trail meets the Lower Kid Goat crag. Is immediately right of a large prominent tree growing approx. 15m up the wall.

Bolted and bolted anchor

Climb up through slabby rock.



Farthest right line on the crag (where there is an obvious groove where the crag ends)

Bolted with bolted anchor

Like Daylight Sailing, this climb is currently in its original condition and is not recommended. It climbs the steep wall right of Daylight Sailing, crosses that route at about half height, and then follows a parallel line a short distance to the left.



Start by scrambling up the broken ground immediately left of Gray Waves (see topo of that route) to a tree belay below a steep bay. 

Single Rack

No obvious crux, but climb up through good rock on slab (some parts with limited hands). Made easier if you move too far left or right onto adjacent bolt lines.



Third bolted line from the far right side of the crag (where there is an obvious groove where the crag ends)

Bolted and bolted anchors

A good alternative if other routes are busy. Be careful not to knock down loose stones on ledges at belay stations, and in particular large blocks at the tops of p4/5: P1 35m, 5.7, straight up to ledge about 10m left of tree island. Bit ro between bolts P2, 20m, 5.8, up/left around corner then traverse left to belay under small corner P3, 5.7, 15m, up corner and then right and up P4, 50m, 5.7, up face to the right, carry on up on runout 5.6 slabs, belay from tree taking care not to knock down large blocks P5, 5.2, 50m, left/up over slabs to exit trailD Descend along trail to climbers right, after 10 minutes you'll descend into, and across a creek above a small waterfall. Use belay rings to descend the last 25m. Start to the right of Giddy Goat, and about 10m left of LF corner.

Bolts

P1 - 5.5 35m
Easy meandering climbing to the chains.
P2 - 5.6 30m
Interesting corner and crack system leads up to a fun limestone-style finger/hand crack. 
P3 - 5.6 40m - crux pitch
Easy slab to easy roof, to easy slab, to easy roof. 
P4 - 5.5 35m
More easy slab to easy roof, then walk to the chains.

Rock overall is good quality, and the route is quite fun.
Banff Rock has a detailed PDF available with description and topo of all the climbs on Kid Goat.

This climb has been retro bolted and very little trad gear is needed. It takes a few small cams to BD #1Â  in the second pitch, otherwise it's protected with fixed gear.

Starts under a small cave a few routes climbers left of Grey Wave, and one route right of the tree island.  Marked on the rock with "TWZ".  Descent is via rappels, doable with 1 60m rope
All belays are bolted. There are a few bolts and pitons here and there on the climb. Other than that a small rack is needed.

Climb up featured rock, finishing just right of a right-facing corner. Crux likely is near the second to last bolt, where one must decide between moving left to stay in the corner or moving right to tackle the face (both contain different challenges and movement).



Starts a couple metres left of where the trail enters Lower Kid Goat area. Starts immediately right of a prominent bolder on the ground. 

Bolted and bolted anchor

Kid Goat has several single pitch and multi pitch sport routes as well as a few classic trad routes. The rock type is limestone of moderate to poor quality, though the trade routes are typically of very high quality. Climbing is best on Sunday when the dump is shut down, otherwise it can be very loud while climbing.  
  
 The longest routes are 6 pitches long and come in at ~200 meters. The wall is a great place to try limestone, trad climbing before moving on to Yam. The wall is east-facing and gets plenty of morning sun. It takes longer to dry then Yamnuska, try from April on.
